One way to benchmark Biden's Bipartisan Infrastructure Law:

by Austin Gana Tolentino

After the recent apportionments the U.S. Department of Transportation's Federal Highway Administration has made after the recent passing of President Biden's Bipartisan Infrastructure Law, it is high time to reflect on the current state of the commute, especially as the country mulls over the glacial yet sure return to normalcy. While the Federal-Aid Highway Program seeks to fund state projects through various grants and priority mechanisms, one grant in particular offers the most flexibility in allowing recipient states wide discretion for utilizing funds to satisfy their own needs: the USDOT Surface Transportation Block Grant Program.

Public transport takes a backseat to driving

Comparing where 30 minute gets you in the top five’s big cities

Driving

Public Transport

City’s “Epicenter”

Chicago

Before potential future deductions, Illinois is set to receive $486 million for the Surface Transportation Block Grant Program under the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law.

Every point around the edge of the blue shape, or an isochrone, is where 30 minutes by car will get you from the Loop. The same applies to the green shape for public transportation.

The Loop

5 miles

New York City

New York state has been apportioned $556 million.

Although 30 minutes by car can only slog through so much congestion in New York, it still beats the MTA for distance.

Lower Manhattan

5 miles

Philadelphia

Pennsylvania has been apportioned $571 million.

Center City

Of the most populous cities in the top five grantee states, Philadelphia’s public transport isochrone is the biggest relative to driving.

5 miles

Jacksonville

Florida has been apportioned $690 million.

Downtown

Similar to the Upper Bay splitting up New York’s boroughs, St. Johns River plays a role in condensing these isochrones too.

5 miles

Los Angeles

California has been apportioned $1.2 billion

Downtown

LA sprawls like Chicago but much wider, and yet its public transport system does not extend proportionally.

5 miles

Houston

Texas takes home the biggest Surface Transportation Block Grant at $1.4 billion.

Downtown

...and in a similar vein as LA, Houston sprawls even further while its public transport is even more lacking.

Note: Using the Travel Time API, the above isochrones were queried for the same departure time of 5pm (local time) on Wednesday, March 3, 2022 to simulate 30 minute distances during afternoon/evening rush hour.

 

Data: traveltime.com

30 minutes goes a longer way at night, mostly.

Another way to evaluate the current state of commute to establish a baseline is to look at the gap between rush hour traffic (around 5pm) and late night traffic (11pm):

Evidently, driving in Houston during rush hour is just as busy (or calm, rather) as late night traffic. One might take a look at the difference between the 5pm and 11pm isochrones to see where public transportation extensions could be prioritized (i.e. at shorter endpoints relative to the epicenter).

Of course, there are a multitude of other factors to consider when thinking about improving road conditions, traffic performance, and public transportation safety. The point here is to take a snapshot of what currently is the status quo, so we can look back and see how the commute has changed to adapt to our needs or how our needs might adapt to these new infrastructure projects that might never finish.
